docs.snippet: MADRID, Oct. 27 (Delayed)-- There are only three solutions to Spain's present problem and attempts to bring about two of these will be fought to the bitter end, Generalissimo Francisco Franco is reported to have told a group of Army officers in...
docs.lead_paragraph: MADRID, Oct. 27 (Delayed)-- There are only three solutions to Spain's present problem and attempts to bring about two of these will be fought to the bitter end, Generalissimo Francisco Franco is reported to have told a group of Army officers in Toledo Friday.
docs.abstract: Franco cites pol goals, army officers meeting, Toledo; calls for natl accord, bid to opposition; says nation will be friendly only to those nations so disposed; cites mil strength and anti-Communist principles; Spanish trade unionists in London receive warning that 22 Repub leaders are scheduled for trial for sabotage, Cadiz; US, Brit, French and Latin Amer nations aid urged; Uruguay calls for inquiry; Royalist circles rept US refused to accept J F de Lequerica as Amb to US because of pro-Axis activities during war

headline.main: FRANCO CITES GOAL AT SECRET SESSION; Friendly Move by Opposition Only Solution for Spain, Said to Be His Belief Calls for National Accord Secret Trials Reported Uruguay Calls for Inquiry Lequerica Rejected by U.S.

byline.original: By PAUL P. KENNEDY By Wireless to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 (AP) --Getulio Dornelles Vargas seized power in Brazil in 1930 and became President four years later under a new Constitution.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 (AP) --Getulio Dornelles Vargas seized power in Brazil in 1930 and became President four years later under a new Constitution.

headline.main: PRESIDENT FOR 15 YEARS; Vargas Tenure Longest in Brazil History--Quelled Three Revolts
Peron Is Denounced For Clinging to Power

docs.snippet: LONDON, Oct. 29--Agreement on the agenda of the United Nations Educational Conference to establish a world-wide cultural organization has been reached by a working committee of twenty-five nations in continuous sessions since Sept. 26.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 29--Agreement on the agenda of the United Nations Educational Conference to establish a world-wide cultural organization has been reached by a working committee of twenty-five nations in continuous sessions since Sept. 26.

headline.main: UNO SCHOOL BODIES AGREE ON AGENDA; Educational Parley Program Is Drafted by a Committee Drawn From 25 Lands

byline.original: By BENJAMIN FINE By Wireless to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--The new Venezuelan Government of Romulo Betancourt, which came to power with the recent successful revolution, received full recognition from the United States today.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--The new Venezuelan Government of Romulo Betancourt, which came to power with the recent successful revolution, received full recognition from the United States today.

headline.main: VENEZUELA REGIME RECOGNIZED BY U.S.; Byrnes Announces Acceptance of Revolutionary Change After Consultations OIL AFFAIRS SATISFACTORY Caracas Reports Britain, Brazil in Accord--Completes Break With Dominican Republic

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: QUEBEC, Oct. 31--A spokesman for the Canadian delegation to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today called for the elimination of tariff barriers on the ground that they represent one of the chief obstacles to the FAO's program for...
docs.lead_paragraph: QUEBEC, Oct. 31--A spokesman for the Canadian delegation to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today called for the elimination of tariff barriers on the ground that they represent one of the chief obstacles to the FAO's program for ending worldwide hunger.
docs.abstract: Dr G Barton holds tariffs hinder United Nations Food and Agr Organization program

headline.main: TARIFFS HELD BAR TO WORLD FOOD AIM; Canadian at FAO Parley Also Backs Commodity Pool and Distribution Agreements

byline.original: By WALTER H. WAGGONER Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, announced tonight that no question of recognition had arisen as the result of the forced resignation of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil and that Adolf A. Berle Jr., the United States...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, announced tonight that no question of recognition had arisen as the result of the forced resignation of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil and that Adolf A. Berle Jr., the United States Ambassador, had been instructed to carry on normal relations with the new Government.

headline.main: U.S. WILL RETAIN LINK WITH BRAZIL; Byrnes Says Change in Regime Does Not Affect Relations With Our Government

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: MADRID, Nov. 3--The entire diplomatic corps attended a funeral service here this afternoon for Vigilio Sampognaro, Uruguayan Minister, who died yesterday morning.
docs.lead_paragraph: MADRID, Nov. 3--The entire diplomatic corps attended a funeral service here this afternoon for Vigilio Sampognaro, Uruguayan Minister, who died yesterday morning.

headline.main: URUGUAYAN ENVOY DIES; Vigilio Sampognaro, Minister to Spain, Stricken in Madrid
